properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 28 at 9:29AM EDT until August 28 at 12:30PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Duplin County in eastern North Carolina...
Southwestern Lenoir County in eastern North Carolina...

* Until 1230 PM EDT.

* At 929 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing
heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain
have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches are
possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected
to begin shortly.

HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban
areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as
other poor drainage and low-lying areas.

* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...
Wallace, Warsaw, Kornegay, Rose Hill, Beulaville, Deep Run,
Kenansville, Chinquapin, Potters Hill, Albertson, Sarecta,
Magnolia, Greenevers, Pink Hill, Lyman and Teachey.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued August 28 at 8:52AM EDT until August 28 at 2:45PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
* WHAT...River and stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is
occurring.

* WHERE...Portions of north central North Carolina, including the
following counties, Rockingham, Stokes and Surry. Portions of
Virginia, including the following counties, Carroll, Floyd,
Franklin, Henry and Patrick.

* WHEN...Until 245 PM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying
and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads
remain closed due to flooding in the Woolwine area of Patrick
County.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 846 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Flooding is
ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the warned area.
Between 3 and 6 inches of rain have fallen, with localized
amounts of in excess of 10 inches.  Numerous roads are
flooded and closed in Patrick County due to the widespread
heavy rainfall, including in the communities of Woolwine and
Ararat. Significant flooding is occurring along the Ararat
River in Surry County.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Mount Airy, Elkin, Fairview, Flat Rock, Jonesville, Dobson
and Pilot Mountain.
- For flooding safety information, please visit
http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.areaDesc: East Carteret; Ocracoke Island; Hatteras Island
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 28 at 6:38AM EDT until August 28 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents.
For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6 to 9 feet
expected in the surf zone.

* WHERE...The beaches from Oregon Inlet to Cape Lookout.

* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through this evening.
For the High Surf Advisory, from 6 AM Tuesday to 8 AM EDT
Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and
localized beach erosion. Localized ocean overwash will be
possible between Oregon Inlet and Cape Lookout, and may impact
portions of NC-12 during times of high tide. Rip currents can
sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.


* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 6 PM Monday.
properties.instruction:
Inexperienced swimmers should remain out of the water due to
dangerous surf conditions.

Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...A portion of north central North Carolina, including the
following county, Surry.

* WHEN...Until noon EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
River or stream flows are elevated.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 436 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin
shortly along the Ararat and Fisher Rivers. Between 2 and 4
inches of rain have fallen.
- Ararat and Fisher Rivers is the most likely place to
experience flooding.
This includes the following streams and drainages...
Beaver Creek, Beaverdam Creek, and Archies Creek.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Mount Airy...                      Fairview...
Flat Rock...                       Dobson...
Pilot Mountain...                  Bottom...
White Plains...

properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding,
including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather
Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports
and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service
Blacksburg Facebook page and on Twitter.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 27 at 9:48PM EDT until August 28 at 3:30AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Central and southern Mecklenburg County, North Carolina
and northeastern York County, South Carolina.

* WHEN...Until 330 AM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams
and other poor-drainage areas, including parks, greenways,
golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots.  Isolated, shallow
flows over roadways is possible.  A few flood-prone, low-water
crossings may become impassible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 935 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms over the past 60-90
minutes from Fort Mill and Tega Cay to Pineville.  Between 1
and 2 inches of rain has fallen across this area, on top of
1-2 inches of rainfall which fell earlier this evening.
While heavy rainfall is departing the area, excessive runoff
will continue over the next 1-2 hours, causing rapid rises on
small streams and nuisance to Minor flooding of adjacent low-
lying areas.

While streams have receded from earlier heavy rainfall,
including Little Sugar Creek, Briar Creek, Steele Creek and
McAlpine Creek, these streams and associated drainages are
starting to rise again and a few areas may exceed bankfull
levels, flooding adjacent greenways and other low-lying
areas.  Isolated roadway flooding is imminent.

Areas in northeastern York County, near Tega Cay and Fort
Mill, including near Springfield Parkway, SC 160, US 21, and
Old Nation Rd, are also prone to flooding from this heavy
rainfall.  Please exercise caution on area roadways and avoid
low-lying areas adjacent to area streams for the next few
hours.

Fortunately, rainfall is ending across the Advisory area.  No
additional heavy rainfall is expected and conditions will
gradually improve over the next few hours.

- Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Rock Hill, Uptown Charlotte, Central Charlotte, South
Charlotte, Southwest Charlotte, East Charlotte, Northeast
Charlotte, Matthews, Mint Hill, Weddington, Fort Mill,
Pineville, Tega Cay, Lesslie, Marvin, The Arboretum,
Southpark Mall, Freedom Park, Carowinds and The Plaza.

- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become
unstable and unsafe.

NWSheadline: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 330 AM EDT MONDAY

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 27 at 9:09PM EDT until August 28 at 3:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Central and southern Union County, North Carolina

* WHEN...Until 300 AM EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams
and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways,
boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots.
Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible.  A few flood-
prone, low-water crossings may become impassible

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 858 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms are ongoing across
central and southern Union County.  Areas of southwest Union
County, including Waxhaw, Mineral Springs, and Wesley Chapel,
have seen 1-2 inches of rain fall in an hour, which is
causing excessive runoff and rapid rises on small streams.
Nuisance to minor flooding of adjacent low-lying areas is
imminent and other areas of flooding may develop over the
next 1-3 hours as heavy rainfall persists from Waxhaw to
Monroe to Marshville.

Areas of greatest concern for flooding include areas between
Waxhaw, Mineral Springs, and Wesley Chapel within the
Twelvemile Creek watershed, along and north of NC 75
including near Waxhaw-Indian Trail Rd, Pleasant Grove Rd,
Shannon Rd, Billy Howe Rd, New Town Rd, Potter Rd, and Old
Waxhaw-Monroe Rd.  Please exercise caution on area roadways
and avoid low-lying areas adjacent to area streams for the
next few hours.

- Additional rainfall of 1-2 inches is possible over the next
60-90 minutes.  A Flash Flood Warning may be needed if
ongoing storms do not dissipate within the next hour.  Please
stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground if
you are in an area vulnerable to flooding.

- Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Monroe, South Charlotte, Indian Trail, Weddington,
Unionville, Wesley Chapel, Wingate, Waxhaw, Mineral Springs,
Marvin, Sturdivants, Jaars and Trinity.

- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 27 at 8:16PM EDT until August 28 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...The beaches from Oregon Inlet to Cape Lookout.

* WHEN...Through Monday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 6 PM Monday.
properties.instruction:
Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

following counties, Cumberland and Sampson.

thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin

properties.areaDesc: Alleghany, NC; Ashe, NC; Watauga, NC; Wilkes, NC
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 27 at 4:50PM EDT until August 27 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.

* WHERE...A portion of northwest North Carolina, including the
following counties, Alleghany NC, Ashe, Watauga and Wilkes.

* WHEN...Until 530 PM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Overflowing poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 440 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rain due to showers and thunderstorms.
Excessive rainfall in some areas will result in flooding of
low-lying, flood prone, and poor drainage areas. Between 1
and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen in some parts of the Flood
Advisory area. Rainfall has diminished in intensity and
coverage, but additional rainfall up to an inch is possible
over the next hour or so.
- Some areas within the advisory area most susceptible to
flooding include:
Lansing in northern Ashe county, areas along U.S. Highway 221
between Jefferson and Scottville, and between Millers Creek
and Boomer in southeastern Wilkes County.

This includes the following streams and drainages...
Beaver Creek. Beaverdam Creek. Big Horse Creek. Basin Creek.
Beech Creek. and Bee Tree Branch.
Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 1.5 inches are expected
over the area. This additional rain will result in minor
flooding.
- Some locations that may experience flooding
include...Boone...                           North
Wilkesboro...
Wilkesboro...                      Sparta...
Jefferson...                       West Jefferson...
Blowing Rock...
- For additional information on stream, creek, river, and lake
levels please visit our web site located at:
http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Statements:  In hilly terrain there are
hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in
heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate
route.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding,
including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather
Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports
and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service
Blacksburg Facebook page and on Twitter.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 27 at 2:37PM EDT until August 27 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...A portion of northwest North Carolina, including the
following counties, Alleghany NC, Ashe, Watauga and Wilkes.

* WHEN...Until 530 PM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Overflowing poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 231 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rain due to showeres and thunderstorms.
Excessive rainfall in some areas will result in flooding of
low-lying, flood prone, and poor drainage areas. Between 1
and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen in some parts of the Flood
Advisory area and additional heavy rainfall is ongoing and
expected to continue for at least another hour or two.
- Some areas that have received the heaviest rainfall this
afternoon include the northern half of Ashe County including
Lansing, Shatley Springs, and Clifton.  Another area of
greater concern is along the Watauga/Avery county line south
of Seven Devils and Foscoe as well as Blowing Rock.

This includes the following streams and drainages...
Beaver Creek, Beaverdam Creek, Big Horse Creek, Basin Creek,
Beech Creek and Bee Tree Branch.
Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are expected
over the area.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...

Boone...                           North Wilkesboro...
Wilkesboro...                      Sparta...
Jefferson...                       West Jefferson...
Blowing Rock...

- For additional information on stream, creek, river, and lake
levels please visit our web page located at:
http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary and Preparedness Actions:

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Find an alternate route.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding,
including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather
Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports
and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service
Blacksburg Facebook page and/or Twitter/X.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...A portion of Piedmont North Carolina, including the
following counties, Cabarrus, Iredell, Mecklenburg and Rowan.

* WHEN...Until 130 AM EDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 1029 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges
indicated heavy rainfall due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding
is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area.
Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen over the past
hour.
- Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over
the area through midnight. This additional rain will result
in minor flooding.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Huntersville, Kannapolis, Downtown Concord, Northeast
Charlotte, West Concord, Cornelius, Mooresville, Davidson,
Harrisburg, Enochville, Coddle Creek Reservoir, Charlotte
Motor Speedway, Lake Norman and Doolie.

Flooding is most likely along Emerson Branch, Coddle Creek,
and Dye Creek.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
properties.instruction:
When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads
or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg
by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our
Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message
should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the
depth of flooding observed.

Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Central Cabarrus County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Mecklenburg County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...
Southeastern Gaston County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...

* Until 1115 PM EDT.

* At 1022 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from near Downtown Concord to near Gastonia, moving
southeast at 20 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to trees and power lines.

* Locations impacted include...
Gastonia, Uptown Charlotte, Downtown Concord, Central Charlotte,
South Charlotte, Northeast Charlotte, Southwest Charlotte, East
Charlotte, Northwest Charlotte and West Concord.
properties.instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Large hail and damaging winds and continuous cloud to ground
lightning is occurring with these storms. Move indoors immediately.
Lightning is one of nature's leading killers. Remember, if you can
hear thunder, you are close enough to be struck by lightning.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by
posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using hashtag nwsgsp. Your
message should describe the event and the specific location where it
occurred.

properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for DAMAGING WINDS. For your safety, move to an
interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. Stay away
from windows.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning.

size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

NWSheadline: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 PM EDT FOR NORTHEASTERN SURRY...SOUTHEASTERN CARROLL AND SOUTHWESTERN PATRICK COUNTIES

properties.areaDesc: Surry, NC; Carroll, VA; Patrick, VA
properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 26 at 6:44PM EDT until August 26 at 7:45PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in BLACKSBURG has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northeastern Surry County in northwestern North Carolina...
Southeastern Carroll County in southwestern Virginia...
Southwestern Patrick County in southwestern Virginia...

* Until 745 PM EDT.

* At 644 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Lambsburg, or
near Fancy Gap, moving southeast at 20 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Mount Airy...
Flat Rock...
Fancy Gap...
Cana...
Pine Ridge...
Toast...
and Lambsburg.
properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds. For your
safety, move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Stay away from windows.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued August 26 at 3:19PM EDT until August 26 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values up to 108.

* WHERE...Portions of southeast North Carolina and northeast
South Carolina.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sunshine, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued August 25 at 4:14PM EDT until August 26 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heat index values up to 107 expected.

* WHERE...Portions of southeast North Carolina and northeast
South Carolina.

* WHEN...From noon to 8 PM EDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat
illnesses to occur.
properties.instruction:
Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out
of the sunshine, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young
children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.

Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When
possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when
possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational
Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent
rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone
overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location.
Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 25 at 4:38AM EDT until August 25 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...Beaches from Duck to Hatteras Inlet.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 8:05 AM/9:15 PM Friday.
properties.instruction:
Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 24 at 8:14PM EDT until August 25 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Friday through Friday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 8:10 AM/9:15 PM Friday.
properties.instruction:
Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

properties.instruction:
Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds. For your
safety, move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy
building. Stay away from windows.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning.

When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of hail of any
size, as well as reports of any wind damage, including downed trees
or large limbs, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free
at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be
shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and
on Twitter.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 23 at 2:46PM EDT until August 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves in the
surf zone.

* WHERE...In North Carolina, the beaches of the northern Outer
Banks including Corolla. In Virginia, the Atlantic beaches of
Virginia Beach.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 4 to 5 ft will result in rough
surf conditions and a high risk of rip currents.
properties.instruction:
Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain
calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired,
float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to
escape, face the shore and call or wave for help.

Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is
extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you
are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at
all times.

Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip
currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many
cases, the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers
from being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it
difficult to return to shore.

NWSheadline: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 23 at 10:56AM EDT until August 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:

a Moderate Risk of rip currents expected.

* WHERE...In North Carolina, Coastal New Hanover County. In
South Carolina, Coastal Georgetown County.

* WHEN...Through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers
into rip currents, piers, jetties, and other hazardous areas.
It may sweep swimmers off their feet, making it difficult to
return to shore.
properties.instruction:
Caution should be used when in or near the water. Check with
lifeguards before entering the ocean for possible hazards you may
be swept into.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 23 at 3:09AM EDT until August 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves expected in the surf zone.

* WHERE...In North Carolina, Eastern Currituck County. In
Virginia, Virginia Beach.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer
head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries.
properties.instruction:
Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is
extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you
are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at
all times.

properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 22 at 8:09PM EDT until August 23 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:
* WHAT...Strong north to south longshore current. There is also a
Moderate Risk of rip currents expected.

* WHERE...In North Carolina, Coastal New Hanover County. In
South Carolina, Coastal Georgetown County.

* WHEN...From 6 AM EDT Wednesday through Wednesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into
rip currents, piers, jetties, and other hazardous areas. It may
sweep swimmers off their feet, making it difficult to return to
shore.
properties.instruction:
Caution should be used when in or near the water. Check with
lifeguards before entering the ocean for possible hazards you may
be swept into.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued August 22 at 12:34PM EDT by NWS Morristown TN
properties.description:
The combination of temperatures in the lower to mid 90s and
high humidity will result in heat index values reaching 100 to
around 105 across much of southeast Tennessee, central east
Tennessee, parts of the Cumberland Plateau and southwest North
Carolina during the afternoon and early evening hours today.


Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. Know
the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Drink
plenty of fluids, stay in air-conditioned rooms, stay out of the
direct sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors that may not
have direct access to air conditioning. Make sure that your pets
have shade and plenty of water, or bring them inside if possible.
Young children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles
under any circumstances.
